qas.question: Which christian philosopher ruminated on time?
What did St. Augustine comment on in Book 11, regarding thinking about time?
Who presented the first philosophical argument for the reality of Creation?
What did Augustine say that the knowledge of time depended on?

answers.text: the knowledge of the movement of things

qas.question: Where did Augustine say time could not appear?

answers.text: where there are no creatures to measure its passing

What does St Augustine think common speech adiquetly describes?

context: In Book 11 of <a0_0><b5_0>St. Augustine<b5_0/><a0_0/>'s Confessions, he ruminates on the nature of time, asking, "What then is time? If no one asks me, I know: if I wish to explain it to one that asketh, I know not." He goes on to comment on <a1_0>the difficulty<a1_0/> of thinking about <b6_0>time<b6_0/>, pointing out the inaccuracy of common speech: "For but few things are there of which we speak properly; of most things we speak improperly, still the things intended are understood."  But <a2_0><b8_0>Augustine<b8_0/><a2_0/> presented the first philosophical argument for the <b7_0>reality of Creation<b7_0/> (against Aristotle) in the context of his discussion of time, saying that knowledge of time depends on <a3_0>the knowledge of the movement of things<a3_0/>, and therefore time cannot be <a4_0>where there are no creatures to measure its passing<a4_0/> (Confessions Book XI ¶30; City of God Book XI ch.6).
